    Dark matter halo profiles pt. 1

    2 minute read

    Galaxy clusters live in dark matter halos. Assuming a spherical matter distribution, the 3D halo density profile can be described with two numbers: the mass $M$ and concentration $c$. This is the first in a series of posts going through the basic maths behind dealing with density profiles, which are studied in a broad range of contexts within astrophysics and cosmology. Here, I will go over how the concentration is defined mathematically.

    The mass of a halo is written in terms of the overdensity of the halo above the background:

    In other words, if we draw a sphere of radius around the halo, then the mass in that sphere is and it is times more dense than the matter density . Ths choice of overdensity depend on the goals of a given analysis (and are often wavelength dependent!). Common choices are 200, 500, and the virial radii . For this post, the definition doesn’t matter.

In other words, the concentration is the halo radius in units of the scale radius. An important point lost on many is that the definition of the concentration is always the same, but its exact value is model dependent. So one can only know a concentration given a halo definition and particular density model (e.g. NFW). Thus, to be completely precise, the appropriate way to denote a concentration is to write it as $c_{\rm NFW,\Delta}$ in order to convey the model and halo definition the concentration comes from.
